headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. My name is Tina and I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Baker Hughes Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn t
componenttext: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. My name is Tina and I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Baker Hughes Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the conference over to Mr. Gary Flaharty, Vice President of Investor Relations. Sir, you may proceed.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tina. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to the Baker Hughes Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. Here with me this morning are Chad Deaton, Baker Hughes’ President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman; Peter Ragauss, Baker Hughes’ S
componenttext: Thank you, Tina. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to the Baker Hughes Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. Here with me this morning are Chad Deaton, Baker Hughes’ President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman; Peter Ragauss, Baker Hughes’ Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Martin Craighead, Senior Vice President and Chief Operating Officer. Following management’s comments this morning, we'll open the lines for your questions. Reconciliation of operating profits in any non-GAAP measures to GAAP measures and results for historic periods can be found in the news release itself as well as on our website at, www.bakerhughes.com, in the Investor Relations section, under Financial Information. And last, I caution you this morning that any company outlooks discussed are subject to various risk factors. We'll try to highlight these risk factors as we make forward-looking statements. However, the format of the call does prevent a thorough discussion of these factors. For a full discussion of risk factors, please refer to our annual report 10-K, 10-Q, and in particular, the forward-looking disclosure in this morning’s news release. With that, I'll conclude our discussion of the administrative details and turn the call over to Peter Ragauss. Peter?

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary. Good morning. This morning, we reported net income on a U.S. GAAP basis of $84 million or $0.27 per share. This compares to $1.41 per share a year ago and $0.18 per share for the third quarter of 2009. Q4 revenue was $2.4 billion down 24% or
componenttext: Thanks, Gary. Good morning. This morning, we reported net income on a U.S. GAAP basis of $84 million or $0.27 per share. This compares to $1.41 per share a year ago and $0.18 per share for the third quarter of 2009. Q4 revenue was $2.4 billion down 24% or $758 million year-over-year and up 9% or $196 million sequentially.For the full year, net income on a U.S. GAAP basis was up $1.36 per share compared to $5.30 per share in 2008. 2009 full year revenue was $9.7 billion, down 19% from $11.9 billion in 2008.  North American revenue was down 31% compared to 2008 and non-North American revenue was down 9%.Looking at quarterly comparisons, North American revenue was $890 million in the fourth quarter, down 37% year-over-year but up 9% sequentially. Revenue outside of North America was $1.5 billion in the fourth quarter, that was down 30% year-on-year, but up 9% sequentially also.Reorganizations, severance, acquisition-related charges and the increase in allowance for doubtful accounts totaled $74 million before tax or $0.16 per share in Q4. This was comprised of $20 million for reorganization costs, $16 million for severance, $16 million for acquisition-related cost, and $22 million for the increased in allowance for doubtful accounts. For the balance of our comments this morning, references to operating profit and operating profit margins will be on an adjusted basis, excluding these charges. On this adjusted basis, our oilfield operating margin for the fourth quarter was 12% down from 23% in the year-ago quarter but up 10% from the third quarter. Turning to the performance of our two segments, Drilling and Evaluation revenue was $1.1 billion in Q4, this was down 28% year-over-year, but up 8% sequentially. The Drilling and Evaluation segment's operating margin was 8% in Q4 that's down from 22% in the year ago quarter but up sequentially from 5% in Q3. Revenue for our completion of Production segment was $1.3 billion down 20% from the year-ago quarter and up 10% sequentially.CT's operating margin in Q4 was 16% and this compares to 23% in the fourth quarter 2008 and is up from 14% in the prior quarter. To help you evaluate our earnings per share in the fourth quarter, I'll review the significant items that bridge the sequential and year-ago quarters to fourth quarter EPS of $0.27. In Q3 2009, our U.S. GAAP net income per share was $0.18. From this $0.18, subtract $0.04 for higher acquisition-related charges, add $0.01 for gain on auction rate securities, add $0.09 for increased profits in North America and add $0.03 for increased profits outside of North America. This gets us to the $0.27 we are reporting for the fourth quarter.Now bridging from the year-ago quarter, from the U.S. GAAP net income per share of $1.41 we reported in the fourth quarter of 2008, subtract $0.03 for higher acquisition related cost, subtract $0.07 as a result of higher corporate expense, add $0.06 for the net impairment of auction rate securities, subtract $0.06 for a higher tax rate and share count compared to the year-ago quarter, subtract $0.56 for decreased profits in North America and subtract $0.48 for a decreased profits outside of North America. This gets us to the $0.27 we are reporting for the fourth quarter.  In Q4, our corporate costs were $66 million in line with our guidance for underlying corporate costs and in line with Q3. Turning to the balance sheet, at quarter end, our total debt was $1.8 billion and our long-term debt-to-cap ratio was 20%. Our net debt was $205 million. Our net debt-to-cap ratio was 2%. We had no maturities and long-term debt until November of 2013.We currently have $1 billion in undrawn, committed credit facilities. We have a $500 million facility, which is accessible through 2012. We also have a $500 million, 364-day facility, which is accessible through the end of March of 2010. We are currently reviewing our options to expand are extend or expand this second facility in light of the BJ Services acquisition.  At quarter end, we had cash and short-term investments of $1.6 billion. This totals $2.6 billion in available liquidity.  Sequentially, we released another $180 million in working capital primarily to our ongoing focus on supply chain and inventory reduction. Last for 2009 as a whole, our free cash flow before dividends and carry over tax payments was nearly $600 million, and this is after taking $250 million of non-recurring charges. Last, a few thoughts on guidance for 2010 and the first quarter. Capital spending for 2010 is expected to be in the range of $1.1 billion to $1.2 billion. Our tax rate is expected to increase to between 33% and 34%. Corporate spending, excluding reorganization and acquisition-related cost, is expected to be $65 million to $70 million per quarter. And finally, first quarter EPS, excluding acquisition-related cost and non-recurring charges, is expected to be roughly in line with the current consensus, which will be a challenge but is doable. I'll now turn the call over to Martin who will highlight our geographic results. Martin?

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Peter. I'll review our international operations first which improved significantly in the fourth quarter with revenue increases in all three international regions.In Latin America, year-on-year revenue was down 11% due to lower activity and revenu
componenttext: Thanks, Peter. I'll review our international operations first which improved significantly in the fourth quarter with revenue increases in all three international regions.In Latin America, year-on-year revenue was down 11% due to lower activity and revenues in the Venezuela, Southern Cone and Andean geomarkets markets. These declines were partially offset by increased revenues in the Mexico, Central America and Brazil geomarkets. Revenue increased 15% sequentially with increased revenue in the Andean, Brazil, Venezuela and Souther Cone geomarkets more than offsetting lower revenues attributable to project delays on the Alma Marine project in the Mexico/Central America geomarket. As is usual for the fourth quarter, we had strong artificial lift and completions equipment sales throughout the region.The operating profit margin in Latin America for the fourth quarter was 9%, down from 21% in the fourth quarter of '08 and up from 5% in the prior quarter. Profitability in the fourth quarter was impacted by lower activity and utilization in Mexico/Central America geomarket in both our Alma Marine project and the ATG activity. Brazil remains one of the most important service plays in the world as we enter 2010. The pre-salt basin offshore Brazil continues to grow as a target of intensive planning and engineering design activities required to develop this basin into a premier producing region. Baker Hughes is well positioned to having committed the technical and operational resources necessary to continue helping our customer optimize their development plans.In the fourth quarter, our collaboration with our customer achieved a record for drilling the carbon inspection of the pre-salt Santos basin. A Tupi well was drilled using Baker Hughes' Quantec bits combined with our TruTrak directional drilling technology and delivered a 37% reduction in the cost per meter than the best previous well in the pre-salt section. The new Baker Hughes geographic organization is also allowing us to re-enter key markets around the world with product lines previously absent. One example is Colombia, where we reentered the market after a long wireline absence and logged an exploration wildcat for the NOC in partnership with an IOC. The well used a full suite of Baker Hughes wireline technologies including our BEACON Center for data management and realtime visualization. Geoscientist discovered pay zones that were previously undetectable with the basic standard issue wireline tools. In Mexico, we remain optimistic of the opportunities as PEMEX explores different approaches to improving the reserve base and the recovery factors. We continue our work on the Alma Marine project with good technical and operational successes. Unfortunately, customer spending constraints of limited near-term activity to three rig, short of the target seven rigs. Under utilization of assets deployed for this project continues to be a near-term drag on profitability.Turning to the Middle East Asia Pacific region, revenues decreased 16% from year-ago levels across all geomarkets with the exception of two. Strong completion system sales in Southeast Asia and artificial lift sales in North Asia supported improved results in these geomarkets compared to a year ago. Year-over-year revenue declines were greatest in the Saudi, Egypt and Indonesian geomarkets. Sequentially, revenues increased 2% as increased revenues in North Asia from artificial lift from completion systems in Southeast Asia and Egypt, and drilling fluid sales in Indonesia, offset lower revenues from the Saudi and India geomarket.Operating profit in the Middle East and Asia Pacific region was 12% in the fourth quarter compared to 23% in the year ago quarter and 12% in the third quarter. A Baker Hughes Centrilift ESP recently set a record in Egypt's Western Desert, completing 10 years of service. Over its life, the pump lifter over 360,000 barrels of oil. Saudi Aramco has awarded Baker Hughes a two-year contract for two fit-for-purpose under-balanced coil tubing drilling packages designed to re-enter existing wells in the gas fields of southern Saudi Arabia. We will provide project management oversight and downhole drilling and completion services including the industry leading CoilTrak, steerable drilling system deployed on coil tubing. Operations are set to begin in the second quarter of this year.Turning to Europe, Africa, Russia and the Caspian. Revenue declined 12% year-over-year in the region as higher revenues from directional drilling, drilling fluids and completions in Norway, directional drilling wirelining completions in Nigeria and strong directional drilling sales in the sub-Saharan geomarket were offset by lower activity in revenues from other geomarkets in the region. The largest year-on-year revenue declines occurred in the Russia, U.K. in Angola geomarkets. Sequentially, revenue was up 11% supported by increases in directional drilling and completion sales in Norway, improved wireline revenue and shipments of completions equipment in Nigeria, sales of bits and completions equipment in Libya and directional drilling and completion systems in sub-Saharan Africa. Our operating profit for the Europe, Africa, Russia and Caspian region was 16% in the fourth quarter down from 22% in the year ago quarter and up from 14% in the prior quarter.Statoil has awarded Baker Hughes' extensions on two contracts in Norway. The contracts are for the provision of drill bits, directional drilling, formation evaluation and related services on 10 to 12 rigs operating in multiple fields offshore Norway. Valued at approximately $270 million, the award extends the contracts through October 2012. In Russia, we awarded contracts for ESP deliveries in 2010 that exceed our total for 2009. Including all of [indiscernible] western ESP award for 2010 and for the third day running, all of Bancorp's ESP needs.Building on this success, we are looking forward to the launch of Ultra-R [ph], a new low-cost yet highly reliable motor, designed specifically for the Russian market. Baker Hughes [indiscernible] AzTrak combined with our third generation AutoTrak system is redefining what's possible in the North Sea. In the fourth quarter, this combination precisely geosteered the well bore through the reservoir all the while staying within six to eight feet from a steeply dipping shale formation.This technology enables Baker Hughes to achieve critical steering control at high build rates with minimum tortuosity and chalk formations while drilling sidetracks and avoiding a myriad of previously drilled wells. Now turning to North America, revenue in the fourth quarter was down 37% in comparison to the year ago quarter but increased 9% sequentially, on increased activity both on land and in the Gulf of Mexico. The North American profit margin was 10% in the fourth quarter down from 24% in the year-ago quarter and up from 7% in Q3 2009.Baker Hughes' drilling and evaluation technology is being used on critical wells throughout the North American basins. For example, in California, AzTrak was used in conjunction with AutoTrak to place a wellbore precisely in the reservoir's sweet spot, just a few feet from the cap rock in a mature oilfield resulting in a's tripling of expected production. And in the Gulf of Mexico, Baker Hughes provided a variety of technologies to enable McMoran to drill and evaluate the recent Davey Jones ultra-deep discovery. HPHT logging tools, Magna Tech drilling fluids, Long-life INTEQ motors, Quantec PDC bits and a Baker oil tools with stock liner system all contributed to the significant achievement. With that, I'll turn the call over to Chad.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Alright, thank you, Martin. Overall I'm pleased with quarter four. We saw a significant improvement for both the North America and the International geomarkets, and we continue to make progress in many different fronts.Q4 was our second quarter of consecu
componenttext: Alright, thank you, Martin. Overall I'm pleased with quarter four. We saw a significant improvement for both the North America and the International geomarkets, and we continue to make progress in many different fronts.Q4 was our second quarter of consecutive improvement in North America as we benefited from higher levels of activity. While the price environment did not change significantly from the third quarter, higher activity on the heels of aggressive cost cutting earlier in the year led to improved profitability and attracted incrementals. Internationally, we did see sequential improvement in our geomarket operations although we still have room for improvement. In the Latin America region, our revenues were down to strongly from Q3 levels and despite lower than anticipated activity levels in Mexico, our profitability improved as we expected it would. We also saw higher revenue in the Eastern Hemisphere geomarkets and a rebound in the profitability of our Europe, Africa, Russia and Caspian region. During the quarter, we continue to fine tune our new organization structure. I continue to be very encouraged by the feedback that I'm receiving from both our customers as well as from our employees. The new organization continued to mature in the fourth quarter, contributing to the improved results, and we expect this new organization to deliver on its promise of increased share and long-term profitable growth as we move through 2010.We're making significant progress towards closing the BJ acquisition and we still anticipate a first quarter closing. Integration teams of both companies have made excellent progress and will be ready upon closing so we can effectively integrate BJ Services into Baker Hughes and implement our operational plan.Looking forward, we are encouraged by the improving rig count in North America. Since the end of the third quarter, the gas rig count has increased to 123 rigs or 17%, with 80% of the activity related to the unconventional shale play. Similarly, the oil rig count is up 140 rigs or 47%, with 80% of activity in the Permian and Williston basins. In some areas of the U.S., where we are again starting to hire, strengthened as the result of strengthening demand for our products and services. And as this demand expands and leads to improved capacity utilization, we will be able to implement price increases.  Obviously, we'll keep our eye on North American gas supply and what this could mean in the second half of this year with regards to land and gas drilling. In the Gulf of Mexico, the lower tertiary play continues to look promising and the recent developments indicate strong potential in the deep gas plays such as McMoran Davey Jones prospects. During the fourth quarter, two new build deepwater rigs entered the market, and we expect an additional nine rigs to enter the Gulf of Mexico by year end 2010. Our product line and service capabilities are well suited to the deep gas and deepwater markets, and we've increased market share on new builds coming into the market.We have seen improvement in the Canadian rig count, and we're well positioned for both the emerging shale plays in the Montney and Horn River areas and the current oil sands activity with the recent openings of our new Fort McMurray and the Duke facilities. We see oil directed activity continuing as long as oil prices remain around current levels, thus supporting drilling in both North America and the international markets. Outside of North America, we look for overall overactivity to improve and for our customer spending to increase from 2009 levels. However, price realizations and profitability will continue to be impacted by contracts that were negotiated in 2009.In closing, 2009 was a year of significant change for the industry and for Baker Hughes as well. Our industry is faced with a significant decline in North American activity, and we reacted accordingly emerging with a leaner, more focused organization. We also set a new course for the company by implementing a new geomarket structure that is improving our market visibility, our efficiency and our customer intimacy. Our supply chain initiatives and outsourcing programs, we are driving efficiency throughout the organization, which will enhance our profitability. And last, by setting the motion in the acquisition of BJ Services, will add the portfolio breadth and capabilities that will make us a much stronger competitor in both the North America and international markets. Finally, I do know that many of our employees listen to these calls, I just want to take a minute and thank them for their efforts in Q4. I know that without a doubt, they put in a lot of hours, especially over the year end holiday season in order to get the orders booked and out the door prior to the year end close. So just a quick note of thanks to them. And Gary, let's go ahead and open up for questions.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010

componenttext: Thank you, Chad. At this point, I will ask Tina to open the lines for your questions. To give everyone a fair chance to ask a question, we do ask that you limit yourself to a single question and a related follow-up question. Tina, could we have the first question, please.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our first question will come from the Bill Herbert with Simmons & Company.
componenttext: Our first question will come from the Bill Herbert with Simmons & Company.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, Chad, could you just comment in terms of what you're seeing, on a leading edge basis, with respect to your different product lines and service lines, on the North American pricing front?
componenttext: First of all, Chad, could you just comment in terms of what you're seeing, on a leading edge basis, with respect to your different product lines and service lines, on the North American pricing front?

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well let me put it this way. We're not seeing the price deterioration anymore. I think if you kind of look at the different ones, that ones that tend to get a little bit tight right now, they are the ones where I think we'll start leaning a bit pricing. B
componenttext: Well let me put it this way. We're not seeing the price deterioration anymore. I think if you kind of look at the different ones, that ones that tend to get a little bit tight right now, they are the ones where I think we'll start leaning a bit pricing. Bits, we had some market share gain in bits in the fourth quarter and it's starting to get tight for the quarter. So I think bits was typically used, reaction will be one of the ones to lead when it goes down. Our C&P side of the business continues to held up fairly well. They're not hit as hard as D&E so that will slowly come back in pricing as it tightens. Some on the D&E side, some of the directional drilling and WD-type work is becoming much more critical with these horizontal wells. So I think that we're going to start seeing that does kind of leave the big players with a better chance to start improving pricing as time goes on. I would say that's kind of the breakdown.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: So when we're talking about what focus on where we're sort of reasonably tying here bits in D&A given the service intensity of the shale plays at the longer laterals et cetera, do we expect to see -- I mean, is pricing beginning to move there on that fron
componenttext: So when we're talking about what focus on where we're sort of reasonably tying here bits in D&A given the service intensity of the shale plays at the longer laterals et cetera, do we expect to see -- I mean, is pricing beginning to move there on that front, or do we expect to start seeing an inflection sometime this quarter?

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: It's not moving yet, and it just depends on if this activity the rig count still continues to climb 20, 30 rigs a week, then I would think by the end of this quarter, early second quarter, we could possibly see some chances to raise some prices.
componenttext: It's not moving yet, and it just depends on if this activity the rig count still continues to climb 20, 30 rigs a week, then I would think by the end of this quarter, early second quarter, we could possibly see some chances to raise some prices.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, with regard to the first quarter guidance and reaffirming consensus, which is I think in the neighborhood of $0.37 to $0.38, we printed $0.42 to $0.43 clean, if you break down what the likely evolution is for the first quarter, North Am
componenttext: And then secondly, with regard to the first quarter guidance and reaffirming consensus, which is I think in the neighborhood of $0.37 to $0.38, we printed $0.42 to $0.43 clean, if you break down what the likely evolution is for the first quarter, North America likely sees a decent sequential improvement off of a strong effort in the fourth quarter, which means that international, if you're going to be having a sequential downtick in earnings per share is likely lower. What's that driven by if that's the right conclusion? Is it driven by year-end product sales not being as forthcoming in the fourth quarter as they were in the fourth? And further margin pressure, or what's going on, on that front?

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Bill, this is Peter. Let me start off the answer here then maybe my colleagues can chip in. I think there are a lot of moving parts to look at, a lot of factors that play in to Q1. Typically, we usually have a stronger fourth quarter. We described that wi
componenttext: Bill, this is Peter. Let me start off the answer here then maybe my colleagues can chip in. I think there are a lot of moving parts to look at, a lot of factors that play in to Q1. Typically, we usually have a stronger fourth quarter. We described that with the pull [ph] forward revenue in the press release, but there are a number of other things. We had a $0.01 of auction rate securities gain which won't repeat. The Venezuela devaluation, preliminarily, our estimates, that could cost us a $0.01. Not a big move, the good thing is we managed that pretty well. And then when you think about what's happening out in the international regions, we had a particularly strong Norway in Q4, and we wouldn't expect that to necessarily beaten Q1, so we see some season pullback in Norway. So in the Urk region, that's a driver. In the Middle East, you've got start-up costs. Mark mentioned the coil tubing contract in Saudi, and we're just getting that geared up, so we're certainly going to incur the cost and the revenues that follow. So typical pattern there with a new project. Also, we've got start-up cost in Iraq. We're making good progress there in getting people on the ground and getting facilities built and getting permits, and that's taking some money, and again, the revenues will follow later in the year. Heading south, Mexico, everybody's talked about the uncertainty in Mexico, and we have our own particular uncertainty in addition to ATG, which is just how many rigs we get on in Alma, and that can swing things quite a bit in Latin America. And then finally, you have the unpredictable weather that could hit you in Q1, particularly in Russia in the North Sea, which we haven't factored in to any of these.  And there's one more in there as well, Bill, is the year-on-year change in pricing international. A lot of those contracts negotiated in 2009, we're going to see the results of some of that in 2010, which I think is what our peers are saying as well.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: So meaning, it's a combination of margin pressure, given pricing concessions of 2009, a mismatch between costs and revenues with regard to projects starting up, Mexico uncertain. Norway, you're not going to get a repeat from a very generous Q4, and then y
componenttext: So meaning, it's a combination of margin pressure, given pricing concessions of 2009, a mismatch between costs and revenues with regard to projects starting up, Mexico uncertain. Norway, you're not going to get a repeat from a very generous Q4, and then you've got some issues with regard to Venezuela and the gain on the auction rate. So that all seems to make sense.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Jim Crandell with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Jim Crandell with Barclays Capital.

componenttextpreview: Chad or Martin, you just mentioned ramping up in Iraq. Do you think that you are far enough advanced now in your presence that you are going to be a serious contender for the first round of IPM bids in fields like Majnoon, West Qurna and Zubair in Iraq?
componenttext: Chad or Martin, you just mentioned ramping up in Iraq. Do you think that you are far enough advanced now in your presence that you are going to be a serious contender for the first round of IPM bids in fields like Majnoon, West Qurna and Zubair in Iraq?

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: We're in discussions with all the players that are out there right now. One are working on things from VP, to ENI, to Exxon, to all the others, as well as the National Oil Companies. We are seeing some business, it has been product sales and things pickin
componenttext: We're in discussions with all the players that are out there right now. One are working on things from VP, to ENI, to Exxon, to all the others, as well as the National Oil Companies. We are seeing some business, it has been product sales and things picking up. We expect that perhaps we'll even do some of our first on-the-ground work by the end of Q1 for some couple of areas. Of course, one of the areas that the clients are looking to Baker Hughes for help is in the area of improving existing production. Of course, that's through downhole pumps and chemicals and other things. So we think that's going to be one of our early areas that will be volume [ph] out. Martin, do you want to make any comments? And then can you just talk to our advise [ph] down there?

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess the only thing I'd add is I'm absolutely confident that our position is every bit as strong as anyone else's. We said that a few months ago in Celle. Our relationship with the NOC there is extremely good. We have a great brand and great reputation
componenttext: I guess the only thing I'd add is I'm absolutely confident that our position is every bit as strong as anyone else's. We said that a few months ago in Celle. Our relationship with the NOC there is extremely good. We have a great brand and great reputation. As Chad said, we've been selling reputable products in there a long time. Our management team is evolving. We've had a pretty good presence in terms of executive visits both here from Houston as well as from the region into Iraq. Our hiring program is well ahead of schedule. Turn to the engineering talent, the Iraqi engineers. And in terms of the bids, we already have bids on the table submitted. I don't want to say for which one in case may be our competitors missed it, but I'm very satisfied. In terms of when it's all going to happen, that's a big question, but steady as she goes.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: So I'm thinking that answer meant a yes, you do think that your a serious competitor to win some of these initial big IPM awards. You never quite answered it that way, but I'm not taking it that way. And follow up is, on the new deepwater rigs that are co
componenttext: So I'm thinking that answer meant a yes, you do think that your a serious competitor to win some of these initial big IPM awards. You never quite answered it that way, but I'm not taking it that way. And follow up is, on the new deepwater rigs that are coming to the market, not market share in Deepwater overall, but for the new rigs that are coming on to the market, both on the drilling side and the completion side, how do you feel you're doing in placing your products on those rigs in both segments?

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: If you look at the four that just recently entered the Gulf of Mexico, we were successful in the areas of sand control, completion tools, upper completion, MWD, LWD, drilling fluids, fishing tools, mud logging, wireline logging and the nine that are enter
componenttext: If you look at the four that just recently entered the Gulf of Mexico, we were successful in the areas of sand control, completion tools, upper completion, MWD, LWD, drilling fluids, fishing tools, mud logging, wireline logging and the nine that are entering in 2010. What's been tendered so far, we won 31% of what is tendered so far for our part of services. So we're happy with that number, Jim. That's above what our market share is right now in Deepwater, so that we like what -- we've been awarded for Watchiskanin [ph] recently, and we like where we stand in terms of what the nine coming in, in the Gulf of Mexico. And, of course, in Brazil, which is the next hotspot, we're very well represented down there with even higher market share. So we're winning our share.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you review how you're integrating BJ Services into the company? Will they have a product line focused still at BJ for at least the period of time, or will it just be integrated regionally right into the company as it exists today?
componenttext: Can you review how you're integrating BJ Services into the company? Will they have a product line focused still at BJ for at least the period of time, or will it just be integrated regionally right into the company as it exists today?

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, internationally, it will be integrated pretty quickly, Jim, because already -- hopefully, will get disclosed by the end of this quarter. But the integration team, as I made it in my comments, has been working on both sides in order to be able to pul
componenttext: Well, internationally, it will be integrated pretty quickly, Jim, because already -- hopefully, will get disclosed by the end of this quarter. But the integration team, as I made it in my comments, has been working on both sides in order to be able to pull the trigger on this soon. And internationally, we see this happening fairly quickly. Domestically, it's probably going to take a few months to get everybody on the ground and get to know everybody, get to people and get their people into key positions, but we think that over a couple of three quarters that will integrate it well. Now there will be obviously a product line and pressure pumping just like there's a product line in bits for us. But from the operational side in the field, we'll integrate quickly and co-locate where we can and work together on these packages.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010

componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Ole Slorer with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: When it comes to the integration of the new geomarket management structure, which can be disruptive in some cases, took a lot of other companies, where do you feel you stand now in terms of having this structure optimized?
componenttext: When it comes to the integration of the new geomarket management structure, which can be disruptive in some cases, took a lot of other companies, where do you feel you stand now in terms of having this structure optimized?

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the field geomarkets are almost completely there. I think we just got another quarter of just final settle in, but all the people are in place. They've now moved. They got their teams together. The sales teams are working exceptionally well togeth
componenttext: I think the field geomarkets are almost completely there. I think we just got another quarter of just final settle in, but all the people are in place. They've now moved. They got their teams together. The sales teams are working exceptionally well together. We just travel around and listen to them talk about the packages that they're winning and what they're doing. I think the product line technology side has made a lot of progress in the last couple of months, probably still three or four months for them to kind of get finally organized and in place. I think one of the worries I think all of us had, Ole, was if we didn't have the organization in place, specially geographically, out in the field and then we got the BJ acquisition closed, that will be a lot of no play. But I'm feeling a lot more comfortable that the organization is running quite smoothly now, and we'll be able to handle the integration of BJ here in the next couple of months much better than I think what it could be. So I'm happy. Martin, these guys worked for you. You got a comment on it?

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess the only thing I's add up, Ole, is I'd echo what Chad said, we're very happy, but we're not satisfied yet. I mean, it's uncovering a lot of possibilities, opportunities, but it's selling in nicely, but we still have a long way to go.
componenttext: I guess the only thing I's add up, Ole, is I'd echo what Chad said, we're very happy, but we're not satisfied yet. I mean, it's uncovering a lot of possibilities, opportunities, but it's selling in nicely, but we still have a long way to go.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Talking product lines a little bit, you're very successful, I seem to remember this just before December in being awarded a large extension from Petrobras on all the directional drilling work. I seem to remember there was quite some differences in drillin
componenttext: Talking product lines a little bit, you're very successful, I seem to remember this just before December in being awarded a large extension from Petrobras on all the directional drilling work. I seem to remember there was quite some differences in drilling performance and pre-sold. Could you go a little bit through the circumstances that led to that direct award?

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it was -- yes -- I mean, obviously, there are probably a client that looks at performance not as well as any customer we work with. They really do break it down in terms of their KPIs, look at it regularly. We've performed exceptionally well in the
componenttext: Well, it was -- yes -- I mean, obviously, there are probably a client that looks at performance not as well as any customer we work with. They really do break it down in terms of their KPIs, look at it regularly. We've performed exceptionally well in the directional drilling LWD/MWD side. As you know, Ole, they extended the contract through 2012. We're up to 50% of the business. They do have some new rigs coming on which they pulled us in and asked us if we're ready to take those on and would we go ahead and start gearing up for those additional rigs to make sure we can handle them, which we're in the process of doing. I think one comes in this quarter, and we will take that one over when it comes. So they're just a performance-driven organization looking at greater penetration, non-productive time they watch very closely. This recent well that Martin referred in his discussion was, I think it's 37% improvement in drilling time versus the previous well. So they just really build on -- and there's a lot of feedback that comes back and forth between our company and theirs regarding just continuous improvement. Martin mentioned the BEACON Center. So those are live, that's live data being sent back into their office and engineered working to try to just improve. And of course, I think one of the successes we're having now is with the increases of our drilling fluids on these rigs along with -- in a bit that Hughes has make some significant gains on the bit side down there. So it's really a system approach now. We let the whole bottom, whole assembly bits, fluids, and it's just ending up with better results.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of your organization down there, they will remember what happened in 2008 when they took the cost of building this thing out before the revenue came along. Are you now at a more balanced organization relative to the incremental rig scope
componenttext: And then in terms of your organization down there, they will remember what happened in 2008 when they took the cost of building this thing out before the revenue came along. Are you now at a more balanced organization relative to the incremental rig scope?

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: We're clearly are on the DDMWD side. That's now in place. We're still building out on the fluid side. We went from a few percentage point of the market share talk to up to 50, so there's still a lot of build up there, Ole. But the bit side, the directiona
componenttext: We're clearly are on the DDMWD side. That's now in place. We're still building out on the fluid side. We went from a few percentage point of the market share talk to up to 50, so there's still a lot of build up there, Ole. But the bit side, the directional drilling side, the INTEQ side et cetera, we're pretty much that. That's just now adding additional cost, additional people as we gear up these next few rigs. But we got our cost in line there.

componenttext: I think, clearly, when the time comes and that starts, we will. I mean, especially one of the big benefits we're going to have now is Portuguese and Angola, and our size in Brazil is going to help us tremendously with the number of people we have there if we start building up over in Angola. So that will help us along with the expertise.

componenttext: Scott, we don't have a total of that. I mean, some of the big projects we've recently been awarded is the BPS or Bergen work. We got additional work in Brazil. We got the $270 million contracts at Statoil. We've got the coil tubing drilling contract in Saudi Arabia, I think there's close to $1 billion, I'm just adding up from the top of my head on those four. We've been happy. Put it this way, in the last four or five months, we're pleased with the projects that we've been winning. And I think it comes down to this point and under the new organization, our client visibility, our reaction time is much better than what it was a year ago. So we're winning a decent share here.

componenttext: Has Bergen starting up in Q1, towards the end of Q1. We've got the coil tubing drilling contract in Saudi which will start up in Q2, early Q2 hopefully, the Statoil stuff in Norway is kind of just an on-going project that kind of rolls over. The Petrobras Brazil stuff, there are several new rigs coming in, so that will start up like one is coming in Q1, and then they will add as the year goes on. What have I missed, Martin? Any big ones?

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010

componenttext: No, that's good. Nine rigs in Brazil is here for which we plan to absorb. All I could think of.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then I think, I guess, more generally, when you focus on regaining some of the lost market share, are the major projects going to be an area of focus, or do you believe that there's certain geomarkets where you have a little bit more of an edge, or is
componenttext: And then I think, I guess, more generally, when you focus on regaining some of the lost market share, are the major projects going to be an area of focus, or do you believe that there's certain geomarkets where you have a little bit more of an edge, or is there going to be more product specific, we think, the share gains are going to be the easiest? How do you think about that more broadly?

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me try to answer. I guess we don't, but I'm not sure I understand the question. Please ask it again. obviously, as Chad kind of said earlier, our reputation in performance drilling is a heck of a push in places like Brazil. As the previous fellow talk
componenttext: Let me try to answer. I guess we don't, but I'm not sure I understand the question. Please ask it again. obviously, as Chad kind of said earlier, our reputation in performance drilling is a heck of a push in places like Brazil. As the previous fellow talked about West Africa, there's going to be a big issue with reliability and again, performance drilling. So I'd say that our share gains will continue to be in the D&E area. That's not to say though that on the C&P side we have anything to give up on. Geographically, we're happy with our present situation in Mexico. I think a small presence in the ATG work is turning out to not be a bad thing, and certainly where we are working there we're with the local companies. I don't foresee any rig reduction for the local companies and the ATG. And that is our client, if you will. And while the utilization offshore is not great, it's giving us good scale presence, which we didn't have before. And in North America, that's our bread and butter, we have a very strong brand. And whether it's in the oil recovery or the gas Wells, again it's going to work well for us. I think it gets all back though to this geomarket organization, where we're just seeing so many more opportunities than we've ever been able to see before. So I'm pretty bullish across the various product lines as well as the geographies.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll give an example where I think that Martin's comment about geographical organization -- I took a trip right after the first year it hit a few geomarkets around and in one of them I was talking to the sales team. And it threw a number out and said sinc
componenttext: I'll give an example where I think that Martin's comment about geographical organization -- I took a trip right after the first year it hit a few geomarkets around and in one of them I was talking to the sales team. And it threw a number out and said since the new organization went in place with this last three or four months, we've made $100 million in this particular area on revenue. And when I asked the question, well how much of that would you have -- and they talked to the bundled services. And I said, how much of that would you have had anyway? Hughes Christensen, or in INTEQ, or whatever would've won just because of the relationship with a client. And they knew the number, they said 71 million. The 29 additional million was awarded because we asked -- since when we got the debt, why don't we get the fluids too because they worked well together. So again, it's that opening comment when I said the sell teams, it's one of the exciting parts about this organization. They are really out there working together. People selling drilling fluids jobs and drilling fluids people selling INTEQ jobs and of course they can't answer all the technical questions but they get in the door and say, "we can also do this for you." So that part I think is in areas where the bundling is much important. I think this is going to help us in 2010.

componenttextpreview: Let me take a stab at that. That's a tough one for us. We don't any permanent installations, so to speak, yet. We're not in the cementing business. To say that CapEx is dedicated towards a certain rig -- I mean, all of our assets are fungible. They either
componenttext: Let me take a stab at that. That's a tough one for us. We don't any permanent installations, so to speak, yet. We're not in the cementing business. To say that CapEx is dedicated towards a certain rig -- I mean, all of our assets are fungible. They either go on the rig or they come off. Hopefully they go on more than the opposite. That's a really tough thing to nail down. But certainly with that growth, as we said, the nine rigs coming into Brazil. And finally to get our share, you could probably look at around 20% of that rental to CapEx at least is oriented towards that rig growth.

componenttext: This year, part of that will be we are building a new 300-foot stimulation vessel. And that as Baker Hughes, so some of that CapEx obviously goes to the Deepwater CapEx. It's for sand control.

componenttext: One of the bids have already been submitted. I mean that means it's on the table already in the customer's hand. Another request has come out, and either pretty significant. Parallel to that, and I think you're probably referring to the IOC awards, parallel to that, the National Oil Company isn't sitting idle either. They're soliciting inquiries for service equipment, wireline trucks, drilling tools and some infrastructure in terms of mud plants to be brought into the country. As I said earlier, I think to Jim's question, we've got quite a contingent in and out, as I'm sure competitors do as well. In terms of when it will actually happen, I think you'll see service revenue in Baker Hughes in Q1 towards the end, and then building from there. But in terms of the big IPM [integrated project management] Projects, our customer, the IOCs are the ones that have to answer that, ultimately.

componenttext: About Iraq?

componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, but I think your first path is going to be a little like West Siberia 10 years ago or 12 years ago when it opened up. I think people are going to get in there. The first thing they're going to try to do is just improve production, basic production fr
componenttext: Yes, but I think your first path is going to be a little like West Siberia 10 years ago or 12 years ago when it opened up. I think people are going to get in there. The first thing they're going to try to do is just improve production, basic production from basic wells. And that means it goes back to bottom hole ESP pumps, chemicals, workover-type programs, may be some kickoffs or small laterals. And then, as that production comes up, and they get some cash flow and other things, then I think we'll start seeing a step out into deeper, more challenging wells, directional wells, et cetera. I think the first year, year and a half it's really going to be focused on just improving basic production.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010

componenttext: Yes, I think. To answer your question too regarding pricing, the pricing is going to be good. Problem is, it's going to be heck of an expensive place  to operate in the early stages. Infrastructure-wise as well as security wise, salaries and wages and those kind of things. But from a pricing standpoint, it should be very, very good.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: It's already a big area for us. Russia's showing some life, it's coming back. We are successful with two key clients there on ESP sales. Already, in terms of these ESP sales for 2010, already exceeded where ESP sales were for all of 2009. Critically, one
componenttext: It's already a big area for us. Russia's showing some life, it's coming back. We are successful with two key clients there on ESP sales. Already, in terms of these ESP sales for 2010, already exceeded where ESP sales were for all of 2009. Critically, one of them was for all their work in Eastern Siberia, Van Koort [ph]  Project, which gets a lot of exposure. You got three main key customers there that have plans to increase our type of spending CapEx about 17% in 2010. We have good relationships with all three of those clients. So I think of course we'll see a breakup come up in Russia. End of Q1, Q2 may not be very good but our Q3, Q4 we see Russia improving considerably. And also of course the Caspian is fairly active right now and there's some big projects coming out there that we've tendered for that we hope to be able to win.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: We think that we agree with these comments that some of periods that's talked about it's moving a little bit away from an IPM to more PEMEX calling the shots and awarding of contracts, which we think is beneficial to Baker Hughes. We have continuously pus
componenttext: We think that we agree with these comments that some of periods that's talked about it's moving a little bit away from an IPM to more PEMEX calling the shots and awarding of contracts, which we think is beneficial to Baker Hughes. We have continuously pushed down there that some of the things that they need are not just low-cost incentive projects but to try to develop technology more and use technology more, not that some of our peers can't obviously provide that as well. But we think that we're in pretty good shape with PEMEX, especially on Alma, some of the things that we've been able to try to introduce there on Alma, and as well as on the ATG with some of the, couple of the horizontal drilling and Frac-Point and other things. So as Martin said, perhaps it's best we weren't heavily into ATG like some of the others. But we like our position there right now and we don't have a huge exposure but they clearly know us we got some real opportunity to work with and to help solve some of these technical challenges.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Steven, this is Martin. Let mu just add one thing to that. I think the jury's been down down there. Finally, the complex reservoir, it's shallow but that doesn't mean it's easy to produce out of. Getting those well down to $1 million a well lets very litt
componenttext: Steven, this is Martin. Let mu just add one thing to that. I think the jury's been down down there. Finally, the complex reservoir, it's shallow but that doesn't mean it's easy to produce out of. Getting those well down to $1 million a well lets very little margin for any of the service companies participating. We avoided it. And it didn't reach the NPV hurdles or whatever they needed down there in terms of PEMEX. Production just didn't get there. So back to Chad's comment, the real value that's going to be provided in that reservoir for PEMEX, and you know how critical that reservoir is on the hills of Cantrell's decline, it's going to be in the hands of the service companies. They're going to be able to work with them show them what the issues are and how the technology we have or our competitors have in their portfolio and leverage it. It's not to say that the factory approach is wrong. It works in some places but I don't see that being the long-term solution in Chicontepec.

componenttext: But Geoff, to say we were surprised, we were above our expectations in that we had at the beginning of the quarter. But we did have a strong December pretty much across the board. So to say it's a surprise, I mean yes, the market reacted pretty well for us.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
